[sarcasm]Move over Ayn Rand because Deborah Blum has a new book out that is going to replace Atlas Shrugged on the bookshelves of every anti-government, tax-hating, freedom-loving libertarian out there (assuming they can buy it with bitcoin). It’s The Poison Squad: One Chemist's Single-Minded Crusade for Food Safety at the Turn of the Twentieth Century. I know what you’re thinking … what does “food safety” have to do with the elevation of ‘greed’ to a moral imperative? Nothing I’m afraid. But what Blum’s book does do is describe a libertarian utopia in terms so vivid and compelling it will make your ‘taxation is theft’ poster look like liberal propaganda. She describes a vision of a possible future derived from the past. A time before any regulatory or enforcement mechanisms existed relating to the labeling or safety of the U.S. food supply. When grocers, packagers and distributers were free to do whatever they wanted … and what they wanted was to make as much money as possible through adulteration of the food supply.It was a time when the name on the food package didn’t have to match its contents. Thus:Ground spices might contain dirt, shells, twigs, leaves, sand, clay or floor sweepingsHoney and maple syrup might be nothing more than corn syrup and colorantVegetables could be made to look fresh and green with copper sulfateCitrus juice could be mixed with sulfuric acidTea might be dried leaves of any typePatent medicines contained things like opium, cocaine, grain alcohol, turpentine or laxativesMilk was often watered down then adulterated with gypsum, plaster of paris and pureed calf brains to make it look white and frothyThen there were the preservatives. Remember that this was a time before refrigeration became widespread. When people had cold cellars or ice boxes (literally, boxes with ice in them). But food still had to be transported from farm to market and spoilage was rampant. If you were lucky, the food was treated with less harmful substances like borax, if you were unlucky … formaldehyde or salicylic acid. Soldiers in the field would complain about receiving “embalmed beef” rations, and being sickened by the chemical odor when opening cans of food, and children would occasionally sicken or die from arsenic and lead used as dyes in candy. But the real tragedy is that these ingrates simply didn’t realize they were living the free-market dream. Liberty was ultimately curtailed with the ratification of The Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, the first of a series of significant consumer protection laws which was enacted by Congress, and it’s only gotten worse since then. It seems the nanny state, as embodied in the Food and Drug Administration, doesn’t believe that ‘poison’ (aka ‘freedom’) has any place in the food supply. Sad.[/sarcasm]The Poison Squad is the biography of Harvey Washington Wiley, a chemist at the Department of Agriculture who launched a crusade against food adulteration and later served as the first commissioner of the United States Food and Drug Administration. According to Wiki: “ Many libertarian philosophers cite Wiley's work as a cornerstone to increasing the breadth and depth of state coercion in the United States, arguing that freedom in medicine, food, and the right to bodily self-ownership began a sharp decline with his measures. Which is ample evidence as to the absence of serious libertarian thinkers as well as why there are no libertarian governments in the world and never will be. As to the book, I thought the first third was quite good, mainly due to the salacious and nausea-inducing nature of Blum’s descriptions of horrible crap found in food. The latter two thirds largely details the political jockeying that takes place as part of getting a new consumer protection law passed, and was about as interesting as it sounds.

The Poison Squad is the 2019 Big Read Book for the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus. Deborah Blum provides a graphic history of the fight for the 1906 Pure Food and Drug Act and the subsequent battle over enforcement of the law, then popularly known as "Dr. Wiley's Law" named for the main character of the book - Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley. The late 19th and early 20th century featured food processors who discovered that chemical additives would preserve food but did no testing to determine how detrimental the additives were to human health. For example, formaldehyde was routinely added to milk and then sold to the poor and orphanages. In one case, this practiced killed 400 children in Oklahoma. Wiley, as Chief Chemist of the United States of Agriculture, waged a personal campaign against the adulteration of food and forcefully pushed for food labeling. Powerful forces were arrayed against him, including major food corporations, chemical manufacturers, grocers, whiskey blenders, etc. Year after year bills for pure food failed to pass Congress because of the lobbying efforts and moneyed interests of the food industry. Wiley's secret weapon turned out to be women. The Women's Christian Temperance Movement and strong female leaders such as Alice Lakey, Fannie Farmer, and others became strong proponents of pure, unadulterated food. The "poison squad" of the title refers to the health studies Wiley oversaw. Healthy young men, mostly government workers, were fed carefully monitored diets where specific doses of chemical preservatives were included. Wiley studied sodium benzoate, borax, saccharine, sulfites, nitrites, and a number of other chemicals. These were some of the first controlled studies of the effects of chemical food additives on humans. The eventual passage of the Pure Food and Drug bill in 1906 was a major, but flawed, effort to cleanup the United States food supply. The bill didn't address what constituted adulterated or even "additive". Enforcement was difficult - the federal government had to seize adulterated food and then prove in court there was a problem with it. Wiley worked at USDA for 29 years fighting internal politics and external enemies. Eventually, a much stronger piece of legislation, the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938, creating the Food and Drug Administration, addressed many, but not all of the flaws of the earlier legislation. What is striking about this history is that we continue to repeat it -- even today there are strong political forces to accommodate industry and to find a "balance" between food safety and industry's demand for latitude in government regulations. This book provides an eye-opening view of where America's food supply has been and the need for constant vigilance to keep our current food supply safe for consumption.

I enjoyed this history of the creation of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906. However, I feel like in many ways there’s more to the story and that the book becomes a bit too involved in the minutia in the daily politics of the Chemistry Bureau and leaves out a resolution for some of the points of the story. For example, what ever happened to all of the preservatives that Dr. Wiley suspected were harmful. Did the FDA eventually ban or limit all of these? The answer in some cases (borax, formaldehyde, etc) is yes. Others are less clear. Wikipedia says that Sodium Benzoate is generally considered safe. How and when did the public health community reach that consensus? Doesn’t this now accepted science which runs counter to Dr. Wiley’s advocacy suggest he may have been too zealous on some issues? Or was this just a limitation of the science that was available at the time?Similarly, when did saccharine fall out of use? And when did full labeling of ingredients on packaging become required? Was it a result of a piece meal approach (as suggested by the conclusion of the saccharine story) or was a there a major regulatory/legislative change? All of the discussion about what makes a whiskey - how much of this survived Prohibition? Did the repeal of the Volstead act create a definition that favored one whiskey group over another? When did refrigeration limit the need for some of these preservatives? The book later says that some Coal-Tar dyes weren’t restricted until the 1970s. Why did that take so long? It also seems to me there are a whole hosts of modern controversies that have vestiges of the pure (whole?) food movement. What happened to the that movement? How would they view the GMO labeling debate? Or definition of “organic” food? I also feel like some history of science is missing. The setup of the Poison Squad trials seems problematic for how modern medicine might approach the same question. Was this really the best science that could be done at the time? Did others in the academic community try to repeat and verify these tests? Do they reach the same conclusions? If they didn’t reach the same conclusions, what effect would that have had on the mechanism of regulation?

Industry-backed legislators, rampant corporate lobbying, legal loopholes and legislative blockades, limited regulatory oversight, public health crusaders, Monsanto, Coca-Cola, Heinz, etc.,This is not run-of-the-mill 21st century agribusiness but the story of the "Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906," a series of early consumer protection laws to reduce the manufacture, sale and transport of adulterated, misbranded, poisonous and deleterious foods and liquors.Our recent ancestors ate in the wild-west of food processing, where milk was routinely watered down, mixed with chalk and a touch of sweet-tasting formaldehyde. Whiskey was nothing more than mixed ethanol with caramel coloring. Candies were dyed with toxic metals (lead and copper). Rotting beef, cheese and eggs were freshened up with mixtures of embalming fluid. Saccharin was the sweetener of choice (much cheaper than sugar) and was found in virtually all food stuffs. Commercial adulteration became pervasive, cascading a downward race to the bottom, forcing even reputable "pure food" retailers to cut with adulterants just to remain competitive.Countless people died (mostly children and the elderly) from these unsafe foods, practices and preservatives. The food industry profited exorbitantly for low cost additives; they became deeply invested and fought tooth-and-nail to stop any regulatory oversight. Such political-corporate cronyism inhibited consumer protection for decades. In the 1890s, Harvey Washington Wiley, a government chemist and untiring pure food advocate, mounted a safe food crusade enlisting the newly formed suffragette movement. After years of losses and dog-nosed drudgery they passed the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, an enterprising yet incomplete set of legislative guidelines for food safety. Much like today’s similarly defeatist drama of politico-corporate caucusing, enforcement of these safe food rules remained in legislative lock-up for decades causing countless harm and untold suffering. This book is the grave yet inspiring account of one government chemist's lifelong advocacy in the rapidly advancing, late industrial, age of chemical agribusiness.Recommended reading for all dietitians, safe (slow) food activists and naive libertarians.

Harvey Washington Wiley, born April 16th 1844, attended Hanover College in 1863 but joined the 137th Indiana Infantry and was deployed to Tennessee and Alabama contracted measles and sent home to recuperate. He earned a bachelor's and then master of Arts degree in 1867 but went on to medicine hoping to achieve a longer life full of health and happiness and hope.He reacted to an article in a medical journal where millions of children were daily dosed with lethal substances.Then it was reported that children fell ill and died after eating birthday cake decorated with arsenic-tinted green leaves. After several other reported circumstances, he wrote that, They poison and cheat the consumer etc etc ...Consequently, in 1881, The Indiana State Board of Health asked Wiley to examine the purity of sweeteners, particularly honey and maple syrup. Imagine, what was sold as honey was tinted corn syrup. The author points out that this corn syrup was not the more recent hazardous high-fructose corn syrup.This started the ball rolling for Wiley and many others joined especially, chemists.He even wrote about artificial butter being sold.Poisonous metallic dyes were discovered in candy. Even coffee beans were lightly coloured to look like the favorite brands.Much politicking had to take place so Wiley became connected to a few presidents, starting with Grover Cleveland, Taft, Woodrow Wilson and Theodore Roosevelt, Warren G. Harding.In 1888, William Lee introduced a bill to label products. Take heed that when people demand bread that you continue not to give them a stone. said Algernon Paddock of Nebraska responding to Wiley's complaints. Wiley had advised Paddock on the food safety act. A film of butter so yellow and sweetWell-suited to make every minuteA dream of delight.So, the author starts the milk and beef chapter. And yet while we eat,We can't help askingWhat's in it?Preservatives and dyes.saccharincorn syrupThe book includes many illustrations and photographs. "The crew of chemists" in 1883 is interesting.A wonderful book for a young aspiring historian.

If COVID-19 is leading you to gain the "quarantine 15," you may want to check this book out. It will definitely help curb your appetite! I discovered this book after listening to and enjoying another book by Deborah Blum. Dating back to the mid-1800's, this book follows the career of Dr. Harvey Wiley, the chemist whose crusade for safer food ultimately led to the creation of the FDA. Though I did find my mind drifting off at times while listening to it, the book was a fascinating look at the additives, such as borax and formaldehyde, which were once considered to be acceptable in our food and how sometimes common spices, such as pepper, contained very little - if any - pepper at all. I did feel there was a bit of repetition throughout the book - ketchup was mentioned frequently before the section devoted just to it, for example. I was fascinated at times by the logic of those opposed to stricter food labeling and amazed to learn how long big business has had it's hand in this aspect of the government. I didn't realize Monsanto has been around for as long as they have, for example. (Or that Nabisco was once called the National Biscuit Company - fun bit of trivia!). As someone who is allergic to sulfites, I found the part of the book addressing its use in foods to be very interesting. Whiskey has quite a history as to what can and cannot be called whiskey! Though this book primarily centers around the late 1800's and early 1900's, it still made me wonder what is lurking in our food and considered acceptable - are there still pumpkin rinds in my ketchup or nut shells in my ground pepper? What exactly are "natural flavors?" Given that it's mentioned in the epilogue, what is the current administration doing to our food we don't know about? Wiley's legacy is quite the story of mostly uphill battles and triumph, but he also faced plenty of defeat as well in his quest to make our food safer and get us to where we are today.

A poignant look at the clash between big business' quest for profit, the consumers' well being, and the governments' conflicted roll in the middle. Although the novel is really about the fight and passion of the formation of what is now known as the Food and Drug administration, this is a good study of capitalism, the need for government oversight and a look at what happens when there is none. It's really a classic story of good versus evil.Fortunately there are people like Doctor Harvey Wiley, who dedicated his life to the fight of protecting people from greedy, unscrupulous organizations that would get away with anything they could to make a profit without regard to the results on their employees or the consumer. Wiley was one of the first people to really look behind the curtain (and under the microscope) at what consumers were actually getting when they purchased a bag of flower, a gallon of milk or a container of cumin. It's unsettling at what some companies were doing to take advantage of the trust of the customer. Although the story does highlight the efforts of some of the larger companies and their efforts to fight these challenges to their profitable yet shady practices, it does show the huge gains of companies who used the newfound food safety knowledge to their benefit. What is stunning is how much this book that really addresses a time from the late 1800's to the early 1900's is eerily relevant today. Not just in the roll of the FDA in protecting the population from harmful food handling practices, but how other government agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency, or Federal Communications Commission, face the same challenges of battling strong companies with congressmen in their corner while looking out for the welfare of the people. And how much money has influence over policy.

Compelling narrative and excellent use of historical data. I have marked this a 2 star, however. The author has a clear bias towards Dr. Wiley and against Secretary Wilson - and a disdain for any with a hesitancy to use federal power. In the author's account Wiley can do no wrong. However, Secretary Wilson who tries to balance various interests while still protecting the consumer is often painted as an enemy. Secretary Wilson served under multiple administrations with very different policy preferences. I wish the book painted a more complete picture of the man. Due to the extreme bias, it's hard for me to believe everything else was portrayed with the appropriate context and in a fully honest way. Those who put harmful products in food and other consumable goods should be liable for their actions, of course, but effecting change through federal policy is seemingly getting more difficult. I think readers would be better equipped to deal with similar concerns today if the book provided more information on how impactful on the market all of the private writings, advertisement, and public education campaigns were, but it doesn't address that question fully - but rather, it seems these efforts were put in the context of growing public support for legal reform. We see that private organizations like magazines and competing businesses, like Heinz, found it profitable to call out the bad actors and inform the public about impure food. I think the average reader can make a bigger impact if we worked in community groups and other private organizations. But, this book, while even pointing out the negative externality of regulatory capture, points to the federal bureaucracy being the solution to all food safety issues - even when the rule of law, as enacted by a democratic government, has not caught up to what the regulators would like to implement.

My husband raved about an American Experience called The Poison Squad, and then someone gave us the book as a gift. Having listened to my husband's comments, I thought it would be worthwhile to read the book to get a better understanding of the issues. Although I never watched the American Experience, I feel certain I made the right choice.The Poison Squad is the story of an unsung American hero named Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley. He was a chemist who relentlessly pursued the investigation of food adulteration. In a way, it was like revisiting some of the issues with American corporate greed that we have today, except that the consequences were even more dire. Dr. Wiley worked in the late 1800's and early 1900's to analyze food and regulate ingredients that were harmful to the public. He was also the driver of food labeling. The stories are horrific and can be illustrated by the fact that arsenic was added to candy and lead was added to milk; they both killed children. The list goes on, but the bottom line was profits - corporations used cheaper products to lower their costs, but the products they used were largely untested and often poisonous.The "Poison Squad" refers to a group of healthy young men who tested food additives and often got sick. They were volunteers who were regularly fed diets that included ingredients that had never been proved poisonous. At every step of the way, Dr. Wiley was hounded by business leaders who resisted his research and tried to persuade politicians to reject his ideas and fire him.The book is well-written by Deborah Blum, who is the director of a journalism program at MIT, and although it dragged a bit with legislative issues toward the end, it was mostly riveting reading. The issues are so fascinating that I recommend watching the American Experience if you don't have time to read the book.

Excellent book!This is the story of Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley, a chemist that led USDA's Bureau of Chemistry at the beginning of the 20th century. The period, just after the gilded age of the late 1800's, was a time when food, as an industry, was gaining momentum. And with it came fraudulent foods, and the obfuscation of ingredients that comprised and preserved the industrial food supply. Whether it was whiskey that was little more than colored ethanol, coffee cut with chickory, canned peas kept fresh looking with copper sulfate, or meat preserved with formaldehyde, there were no Federal regulations relative to food safety. Into this environment came Dr. Wiley, the first true food safety firebrand of the modern era. Wiley was forced to fight the food safety fight on multiple fronts simultaneously, as he attempted to force industry to divulge the ingredients within their products, while at the same time he needed to battle his peers and superiors within the Federal government that were sympathetic to the needs of the food industry. What I really enjoyed about the book was Wiley's insistence upon food safety being driven by science, and while his employment of the Poison Squad was a bit sensationalistic when viewed through the modern lens, it was both powerful and scientifically sound when it was conducted in the early 1900's. The struggle for food safety has not abated over the last 120 years, and they continue to this day, though the chemical ingredients at the center of the issue have changed. The Poison Squad very eloquently describes the beginning of this struggle for product information and the implementation of quantifiable dose/response relationships into food safety.A very readable and well written book. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Goodreads Read Harder Challenge 2019#5 A book by a journalist or about journalism My rating is highly subjective based on my enjoyment, not on the quality of the information. I tend to find most non-fiction rather dry, so don't let my mid-range rating dissuade you from reading this book if the topic interests you. The Poison Squad is an in-depth look into how food safety laws came about in the early 1900s, and how Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley lead the efforts to pass and enforce legislation to make food safer for consumers. It was interesting to learn about how different factions fought for and against the legislation, and how public opinion was turned to ultimately support more regulation. It was also fascinating to see how similar the process is to today, where industry interests continue to fight for less regulation and safety in favor of profit, and how difficult it is to rally the public to support safety causes. The author does her best to use Dr. Wiley as the central figure in order to tell a more cohesive story, but there are parts of the story where he is not so central, so it doesn't quite read like a straight narrative. Plus, in the middle especially, it gets a little slow before the legislation is passed, so there is a lot of back and forth with no progress. This results in plenty of names, dates, and organizations being mentioned, but it can be hard to keep track of. Also, if you are at all squeamish about what used to be put into food, you might not enjoy this book!  It's shocking what manufacturers were putting in food and selling to the public. Not a good lunchtime read, but at least we can feel somewhat confident that it's no longer happening (we hope).

This book was amazing on several levels. First, it was a fantastic summary/introduction/guided tour through the disaster that was America's food supply in the late 1800s and early 1900s. It covers all the "fascinating" bits like copper- and arsenic-based food colorings, as well as the more "mundane" bits like spoiled food or imitation products passed off as the real thing, and appalling tidbits like the wide-spread use of formaldehyde to "restore" or preserve spoiled meat and milk. That alone is worth reading simply for the staring-at-a-car-wreck goggling factor. Second, the authors did a great job of showing all the different parties who played key roles in cleaning up the food supply, willingly or otherwise, and all the ones who stood against such efforts (expected and unexpected). From housewives to government chemists to presidents to military leaders to lobbyists and producers in almost every industry, the lines did not split how one might expect and the history of it is both intriguing and inspiring. Even, dare I say, empowering. Third, the book creates an opportunity for people to explore and educate themselves on food-related issues in a less politically charged climate than we're accustomed to. You know that thing where fiction authors address social injustices or moral questions by setting up situations in fictitious lands or the future, and it makes it easier for people to have open, intelligent discussions about them because they aren't saddled with fears about political correctness or ingrained defensiveness of their political or religious affiliations? This book does that with food, and it's incredible. Everyone should read it, if only for that.

3.5/5 stars. The true story of Harvey Wiley and a group of young men identified as the "Poison Squad" who willingly ingested chemical preservatives and unsavory food substitutes found in diets at the turn of the century in order to bring the dangers of such consumption to the attention of the public. While the efforts of this group resulted in the establishment of the "1906 Pure Food and Drug Act" and later the U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA), it is disturbing to note that the risks these men took ended up being all in vain when loopholes in the legislation permitted the use of deadly substances once again. For me, this book was dry and a bit of a slow starter and, while it does pick up near the end, only slightly. It suffered, too, from a repetitiveness and disorganization and could have done with better editing. Many things I learned in the beginning are rehashed in later chapters multiple times. I also thought the writing lacked the charm of other historical accounts in which personal information about the individual(s) spearheading the movement is included for a humanizing effect. Yet, the history is fascinating and well-worth the time to discover! Perhaps viewing the PBS documentary of the same name would be a more enjoyable way to access that history, though.In short, a shocking, eye-opening story of food industry greed and immorality made even more frustrating by the fact that some of the offenses/abuses against the common man's access to pure/unadulterated food are still happening today.Note:  If you are drawn in by this book's shocking title and/or by the concept of one man's true-to-life quest for the good of all, I recommend The Butchering Art by Lindsey Fitzharris.

Interesting book but bogged down with too many players. It was enlightening to find out that the good old days were not. This book is the story of Harvey Washington Wiley who as Chief Chemist of the Department of Agriculture, led the way to the first real regulation of the food and drugs we eat. At the turn of the 20th Century, manufacturers, farmers, and conmen, were free to doctor foods and drugs. Upton Sinclair’s The Jungle, fictionalized the filth of the stockyards, but who knew that poisons such as arsenic, cooper sulphate, borax and formaldehyde were routinely used as coloring agents, preservatives and fillers to mask spoilage, mold and rot. Milk that did not contain milk; sugar that did not contain sugar; butter that did not contain butter and whiskey that had no whiskey. There was no requirements that labels list ingredients, servings or weights. Dr. Wiley became a hero to consumers in efforts to reveal what the public was ingesting. He had to fight chemical manufacturers, meat packers, his bosses, various presidents to attempt to stop the public from being poisoned. The names are still familiar, Armour, Monsanto, Coke, on the side of the manufacturers and Heinz and Good House Keeping on the side of the consumer. It is easy to look at the seemingly naïveté of the people of this era. However, with the Trump administration rolling back regulations and inspections of our food supply and clean water and air, we could easily be slipping backwards.

A very fascinating look at the food industry in America- and the crusade to make it safe for consumers. Led by the indomitable Chief Chemist Harvey Wiley, it details how tirelessly he worked during the turn of the 19th and early 20th century to bring about laws and reforms for 'pure food.' Food was regularly 'adulterated'- everything from coffee, whisky, candy, flour, milk, meat, butter, canned goods, spices, syrup, catsup, which lead to sickness and death for countless Americans. Detailed in the book is the fight for better regulations, labeling, and holding the food producers accountable. Companies that are still around today are just emerging in the time frame of the book- Coca Cola, Swift, Armour Meats, Monsanto and Dow (preservatives and dyes.) HJ Heinz was one of the first companies to offer a catsup that wasn't loaded with harmful ingredients. Most notable, however, are the marked similarities to our own time- politics, profit over people, regulation (and deregulation), special interests, public outcry and protests, and push back from industry. Wiley was a bulldog- and his work made a huge difference in the lives and health of Americans. Interesting fact- in his later years after retiring from federal service, he went to work for Good Housekeeping magazine, writing a column about food safety and having veto power over any product advertised in the magazine. If it was worthy it earned the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval.

Excellent history of the development of the food branch of the FDA. Inspirational and detailed, present and future activists must read and learn. I have a few thoughts based on reading the book. Too much is still the same - - big buck lobbyists curry favor with decision-makers to the detriment of the citizen. Food safety is still an issue, and nutrition is a sister to safety. Our leaders have not created a plan to de-incentivize fast food, calorie-dense foods, and non-nutritive food choices; big efforts are needed to combat the obesity of America. The leading cause of death by 2030 worldwide is expected to be nutrition-related disease. While some countries starve, we eat the wrong foods. We need universal health care, but we need wellness programs with smart nutrition favored over the bad habits. We also need action to fix our broken election methods that permit big buck groups to donate to candidates. The candidates, if elected, have inevitably biased relationships that affect policy-making. No more donations. Facebook and Instagram and Twitter are cheap ways to get a candidate’s name and positions known. Let’s figure out a better way without big campaign budgets.Pharmaceutical safety, global environmental health and sustainability and so many more issues need the tenacity and integrity of an army of Harvey Washington Wileys.

There is a lot to say about this book. I appreciated Blum's thorough research on the subject. She also reminded us of common practices/ social perspectives "back in the day" that put the whole story in perspective. 1) For instance, women were not allowed to vote, they had zero way to influence their local surroundings, state and national policy. The women's club movement was a means to shape and influence education, temperance, child labor, juvenile justice, legal reform, environmental protection, library creation ...phew! 2) Also, I was struck that journalists were 98% on Wiley's side --I think now how newspapers are OWNED by corporations trying to screw over their workers and readers. Also, at the time, one went into journalism to mostly to advocate for the people. Journalists back then earned meager paychecks and were considered blue collar workers because they had to operate machinery (telegraphs, typesetters and printers) and there was other manual labor, such as sales and delivery. I guess I think of journalists having degrees in journalism and/ or communications...or they get their job via nepotism. I appreciate how all her research and skills produced such a readable and engaging tale. All the political, federal and corporate layers *should have been* a convoluted drag... instead, she cranked out a page turner.

Dr. Wiley and the creation of his "Poison Squad" was an interesting read and character study. What is hopeful is that there have always been earnest and moral individuals fighting for the well-being of the people. What is sad is there have always been greedy, corruptible and callous individuals who want to make money even at the expense of people's health.I found that reading about Dr. Wiley at the turn of the century was inspiring. How he developed his "squad" to investigate and push back against unhealthy practices in the food industry. Deborah Blum did a great job researching about this time and illuminating what was happening concerning the experiments of food ingredients and the politics. It reminded me of Sinclair's The Jungle, Schlosser's Fast Food Nation and Moss' Salt, Sugar, Fat.The politics was disturbingly similar to modern day's politicians backing business and avoiding common sense regulation at the expense of the public's health. These food manufacturers come across as idiotic or indifferent based on today's standards of food purity standards. Hell, they even thought labeling was unnecessary even after people were literally poisoned. Sad that politicians can't see the same thing happening today - or maybe they do and don't care. How many times does one have to see the same thing repeated to know which is the wrong side of history.

Blum does it again (see her earlier Poisoner's Handbook for a different take on the subject of poison) with this book on the push for government regulation of food safety and the impact of Harvey Wiley on the developments that eventually led to pure food laws and more. Wiley is a flawed figure, for sure, but his consistent and stubborn insistence on holding food manufacturers accountable for their practices and labeling must be admired. His decades-long crusade for pure food laws, including testing suspect food additives on young men in controlled environments (who came to be known as "the Poison Squad"), resulted in frustration and pushback from many within the food industry and government, but he was also instrumental as a leader in getting pure food laws passed and ensuring that consumers had the knowledge to determine how they could buy and keep safe food. Government may not be perfect, but thanks to Harvey Wily and those who followed, food safety is something they got right—at least in principle. Would I recommend it? Yes! I think this is a really interesting background for understanding some of how we got where we are today as far as food, marketing, and government regulation. It also makes me think what a miracle it is that our grandparents and great-grandparents survived if they weren't producing most of their own food. Yikes!

It's an interesting read for those interested in governmental regulations and how industry can work to undermine or block them (and the important role the consumers and their advocacy groups can play). It's also memorable for the amazing character of Dr. Harvey W. Wiley that is presented in the book. It's interesting how many of the compounds used in foods that are are discussed in the book (caffeine, saccharin, sodium benzoate, corn syrup, nitrate, and other preservatives) have been the subject of later controversies as well. Perhaps the epilogue could have brought up the more current status of these (how is flour now bleached? How are such high levels of caffeine in energy drinks now justified? What about sodium benzoate, which the FDA now recognizes as "Generally Recognized as Safe"? Why about saccharin, which is still pretty commonly used? As an aside, it's truly amazing how far we've come in regulating clinical trials.I would have liked a longer epilogue. The book makes it seems like the use of any preservative is a negative, but in more recent times, they have prevented many food-borne diseases (botulism, listeriosis); this would have been nice to have been acknowledged.

There is great value in participating in the UW Go Big Read. This year’s and last’s scientific picks really worked my brain and required more time and concentration than I normally dedicate to a book but it was well worth it. The Poison Squad is an in-depth look at the work of early food and drug science and regulation in the United States beginning around the turn of the 20th century.Maverick Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley fought tirelessly to develop a protective system that ensures the safety of consumers and the question now is who will continue that fight in light of current administration that does not care about health, safety, the environment, ethics or morality.Subplots in the book: Wiley’s wife, Anna Keltin, was awesome. She was an early library clerk/librarian at the Library of Congress and suffragette, and Good Housekeeping was rad in a way that I did not appreciate until now.Benefits today due to Wiley’s work:Food labels. Safety testing of new products. Food poisoning outbreaks are monitored and traced. Tainted foods are subject to recalls. Criminal prosecution if food and drug manufacturers cause harm. These same principles are now applied to other protective measures like environmental protections. Thank you, Dr. Wiley and the poison squad!

This is the first book I have read by the author. It is an excellent book. I purchased it because I work extensively with hazardous materials. I have read a few snippets about the adulteration of food products and was familiar with the embalmed beef episode during the Spanish American War and the disgusting practices in city based 'milk factories'. I was unaware of the degree to which chemical additives had permeated the food supply. Rather than enhancing the food quality or diets, they were profoundly detrimental to consumers, particularly children in the case of heavy metals in food coloring. The book describes the founding of landmark legislation to protect consumers and undermining of that legislation by big business and their political hacks. The story is told through the life of Dr. Wylie, of the Chemical Bureau of the Department of Agriculture. It was also interesting to find out that Heinz was a leader in pure foods. The only drawback with the book is that I would have liked to see a bit more information on the chronic effects of the chemicals discussed.This will go down as one of the best books that I have read in 2019. I highly recommend the book for anyone interested in the history of food adulteration, government corruption, and the politics of the early 20th Century. I will definitely look forward to more of this writer's work.

With the rash of bad food safety news and attempts at deregulation, @DeborahBlum’s book, The Poison Squad, couldn’t have been better timed. Reading this will make you an ardent advocate for stronger regulation, not relaxing it. Can you imaging a review board (IRB) now allowing Wiley’s testing of adulterants on healthy volunteers?I’ve regularly written about food safety from the infectious disease or outbreak perspective. This is the other side of the coin, with fraudulent and dangerous food additives.Drug development for safety and efficacy was the focus of much of my professional career. Counterfeit medicines also have a huge overlap with Infectious Diseases, as illustrated by the growth of artemisinin-resistant malaria.Blum’s thoroughly documented, engaging—and at times nauseating—read, is a must-read for anyone who is concerned about health and safety-- in particular, of children. It is graphic, of necessity.The Poison Squad is a call to arms for more safety and protection for whistle-blowers, not a laissez-faire government.Well-deserved acclamation and placement on “Best Science Books” lists.

I was very excited to see this because "The Poisoner's Handbook" was so exceptional. This book is important in revealing how horrific unregulated capitalism can be. No food industry was exempt from protecting profits at the risk of endangering human life. Children were dying, people were poisoned--with no consumer protection from the government or recourse through the courts. Enter Dr. Wiley, pioneer of pure foods, a tireless advocate of food safety. His story, and the story of the horrors of the Chicago stockyards, formaldehyde-preserved milk, and arsenic-colored candy is eye-opening in terms of the lengths the industry would go to for profit at the expense of safety. The second half of the book however becomes slow and bogged down in details of political infighting and litigations. I struggled through the last 50 pages. A more detailed investigation into one of the more egregious poisoning events may have been more engaging. "The Poisoner's Handbook" is better structured as such and remains my favorite of this author's work.

A truly remarkable and informative book on the foundation of food safety efforts in America and the 1906 law that first established regulation and oversight. It explains the science behind the adulterants in question as well as weaving a compelling narrative that steers for a balanced portrayal of people's reasons, so much as they could be known. It so clearly drives home the point that many businesses are truly looking for profit, even at the cost of the well being of people. The examples provided are at times both horrifying and humorous (brains in milk), but the point is also made (even by people at the time) that those who pay the cost for this profit the most are the poor. It often took major tragedies to create the outrage/political will to handle any issue, and the ground had to be fought time and again in case after case. This book is relevant both as history and to our world today. When you think about government and what it does or asked about what point it serves, this is an example to remember.

Enjoyment Rating: 3🌟Writing Quality: 4🌟Audiobook Narration;: 4🌟“By the mid-nineteenth century, in fact, many foods and drinks sold in the United States had earned a reputation as often untrustworthy and occasionally downright dangerous.”- Milk was often laced with formaldehyde.- Brown sugar was often just ground up bugs.- Spices – such as pepper – were usually a concoction of pulverized coconut shells, rope, and floor sweepings – among other things. These statements, horrible as they may seem, are the true story of the US food world in the late 1800s/early 1900s. It was due to the unwavering efforts of one Harvey Washington Wiley (and his many supports) that these unsafe, unsanitary and (quite frankly) disgusting tactics were put to a stop with the passing of the National Pure Food and Drug law. But his enemies in the US government and business world did not make it an easy journey for him. This is one of those books that is both fascinating and horrifying, and it gave me a deeper appreciation for the current food safety laws we do have. Well researched, great audio narrator. Overall I’d say worth reading.

I heard about Deborah Blum’s The Poison Squad while listening to NPR and thought it sounded like a good read. I was wrong, it was a great read. Recounting the history of food adulteration and the battle to consumer protection during the late 19th and early 20th century sounds like bland stuff, but Ms. Blum produces a well researched and written story of Dr. Harvey Wiley’s crusade during his time that is just as relevant today as it was at the turn of the twentieth century. One can’t escape the parallels of the huge power wielded by rich men and corporations who made their fortunes and built their businesses at the expense of the public, and how politicians protected the monied interests as opposed to their actual constituents. Frankly, these echoes of the past sadly reminded me of our current state of affairs. It reminded me how often history repeats itself, and that when we bemoan the present and romanticize the past, we are losing sight that the more things change, the more they actually stay the same. A sad truth brought out in a very good book.

If nothing else this book sure helps one to no longer take for granted, and begin to appreciate the quality of food modernity has granted us access too. At first I was worried this book would just be story after story of gross things being added to food and making people sick, but once it gets going it's more of a biography of Dr. Harvey Wiley who I'm ashamed to admit I had never heard of prior to this book.That said Blum doesn't tether herself to Wiley alone, and she's happy to wander off for extended periods discussing other characters, court cases or historical events I think the book is richer for it. In her depiction of Wiley, she tries to present him as a complex and flawed individual, which I appreciate, but he still felt pretty flat to me as a character.Also the afterward where Blum uses the events of the book to take some swipes at the Trump administration felt a little half-assed to me.

I learned a ton from reading this book. The author chronicles the efforts of Harvey Washington Wiley, a chemist, who became the greatest advocate for food safe in his time (during the turn of the 20th century) during the presidencies of McKinley, Roosevelt, Taft and Wilson. The novel, "The Jungle" by Upton Sinclair also comes out during this time and aided Dr. Wiley's cause to some degree. His work lead ultimately to the creation of the Food and Drug Administration as well as the "Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval". It's also another historical rendering that lets us know that the government is only "for the people" IF the people continue to hold the government accountable. Corruption and undue business interests affecting government regulation is no different now than it was back then (and probably will be in the foreseeable future). It will make you re-think how you view the food that we eat and how things have greatly changed.

Poison Squad is the Go Big Read (UW Madison) selection for 2019. It was well written and there was lots of stuff about the struggles to have safe food that I was completely unaware of. I think we are meant to be encouraged by Harvey Wiley's commitment to battle big business and our elected officials who favor big business over the common man. I came away discouraged however, given the current political climate which leans toward fewer protections and less regulation. In her epilogue, Blum writes, "This sense of deja vu, echoing down the years, should remind us of the ways that food safety practices have dramatically changed in this country -- and of the ways they have changed hardly at all." Monsanto was very influential at the turn of the century and they still are ...... It saddens me. On the other hand, I am grateful that we have food labels and that my butter is actually butter if I read carefully enough.

Dr. Harvey Wiley's biography is a fascinating story in and of itself. The tale of how the Food and Drug Act of 1906 came to be is also quite interesting.The underlying backstory of why such a piece of legislation was necessary in the first place is the real meat here.Reading the details of how 19th and 20th century manufacturers regularly poisoned their customers, the American people, in pursuit of profit, is to read a litany of horrors. Formaldehyde in the milk, arsenic in the candy, copper sulfate in the canned peas, and saccharin in virtually everything - all these facts are laid out and induce an instant recoil of revulsion. The attempts by the purveyors of these assaults on an unwitting public to deny the facts, cover-up their worst excesses, and deny the truth by any means available, provoke righteous outrage.Considering the current all-out attack on any and all regulation being conducted by our current administration, the message of this book couldn't be more timely.

Detailed exposure of the horrible conditions of food and drink (from milk to whiskey) at start of last century prior to the Pure Food & Drug act of 1906 (which still didn't solve everything.)Foods were adulterated with borax, metals, formaldehyde (yes), dirt, animal and insect parts, and other detritus on a long long listFor example. CocoCola did have cocaine and huge amounts of caffeine and was involved in a lengthy trial in 1909, claiming their formula was secret and could not be revealed. Bottles sold as vanilla extract were brown-tinted water. Milk had whitening agents. Sickening examples one after another after another.One man in particular named Wiley led the crusade for clean food for many years against the slaughterhouses, filthy factories and purveyors of death-dealing items. In this he was greatly supported by women's organizations and, interestingly, magazines.

When I picked this book up, I already knew a bit about the history of the Pure Food and Drug Act - I had a high school teacher who loved to talk about it. So I didn't necessarily find the details of just how unsafe our food used to be shocking, per se. But the topic is both very interesting and, as Blum wisely points out, still relevant. Even today there are attempts to relax food safety standards in ways that have consumer ramifications. It's important to be aware of why we have the standards that we have so that, as Blum urges us, we can continue to hold food and drug manufacturers accountable for our food, drink, and medication. Blum does an excellent job crafting a historical account that is relevant in our current era as well. Occasionally the writing is a little diffuse, and I found myself confused in some of the chapter where we were continuously introduced to new people, but I still learned a lot about the history of the FDA!

This book clearly illustrates the double edged sword of government. Around the turn of the century There were no regulations for food safety. Poisons were included in food to improve the color or act as a preservative. Foreign substances were used as cheap substitutes for spices such as walnut shells ground up and sold a pepper. This book chronicles the actions of a small group, working for the government, that were attempting to regulate food, drink and medicine. A prime example of government working for the betterment of society. Unfortunately, just as many politicians, in the pocket of special interest groups, fought against this group of scientists. Sadly, this continues to this day. Healthy food, clean water and clean air should not be political issues. We all drink the same water and breathe the same air, conservative or liberal. This book was entertaining and informative.

This is the Go Big Read book for our university this year. It's a fascinating look at the how and why the Food and Drug Administration was formed. My main take-away from the book is overwhelming gratitude for Dr. Harvey Wiley, a chemist in the Agriculture Department who unceasingly advocated for safe food and drug legislation. It was easy to compare the government's struggle to balance science, consumer advocacy and business interests back then to the current day issues.It's an interesting piece of history, but the book focuses mainly on Wiley's life and advocacy and there is a lot of detail. At the end, the book touches briefly on some more recent food scares and policy issues. For me, I would have preferred a longer section on some of those items. However, I suppose those are left for another book - or as I imagine, quite a few student papers written on those topics.

An excellent, educational read!With the exception of perhaps a couple minor editing mistakes, this was a phenomenal read! I read "The Jungle" years ago and knew some of the history of good safety in the U.S., but Blum's superbly written, thoroughly researched book is a real eye-opener, not just in the evolution of food safety regulations, but in how history under the current administration is doomed to repeat itself. As I read, I was dismayed by how current policies parallel those of the past when science was ignored in favor of industry interests and profits over consumer protection. As Blum states in her Epilogue, "This sense of déjà vu, echoing down the years, should remind us of the ways that food safety practices have dramatically changed in this country—and of the ways they have changed hardly at all."

This book isn't bad. It's a very thorough and alarming account of the food industry at the beginning of the 20th century working really hard to keep costs by adulterating food to the point of literally poisoning consumers. Dr Wiley's crusade to enact legislation that would force companies to be accountable for their actions is admirable and his tenacity is incredibly impressive. That said, for a book about such horrifying subject matter (the stuff found in milk was just repulsive), I didn't find myself particularly gripped by the story. Perhaps because it's so focused on legislation, the pacing can get a bit slow, and I found myself losing focus more than once. However, if you're willing to put in the time, it's definitely interesting to get a better understanding of the roots of our modern standards of food safety.

Read at the recommendation of my environmental toxicology professor!It’s wild to see how little progress has been made in 100 years: the study techniques are still the same (minus the human subjects), and the uncertainty factors nearly as high. The definition of what’s “injurious” to health is still vague and constantly contested. It’s disheartening to read that the burden of proof has always been with the government, rather than the companies that manufacture compounds for human consumption or use.Although food regulation has a happier ending with the establishment of the FDA, I can see many parallels between this and the fight for human impact studies being carried out by the EPA now. Thankfully, the food industry has adapted to and overcome stringent regulations- something tells me manufacturers can do the same if PFAS, TCE, alkylphenol, etc. standards are passed.

Succinct History of Consumer Rights in US I really enjoyed the history of Dr. Wiley and the Chemistry bureau’s efforts to protect the American public from ‘food adulteration’ at a time where industry’s money was stronger than Congress’ will to change. Everything from the lost of ingredients that are required on labels, to the amount that should be in the container is because of Dr. Wiley’s unrelenting view that the consumer should know what they are buying and feeding to their families.Similarities to today’s public discourse of disregarding scientific research and using court cases to buy time or to be found non-liable, were by biggest take always. Unfortunately, too many times on our history is takes the death of children for public outrage to cause regulation changes.

What surprised me the most was how much manufacturers insisted known or highly suspect chemicals, colors and additives remain in food--overwhelmingly they did so because switching to safer alternatives would "hurt their business". We are still hearing that tired song sung today! What's killing a few people and sickening scores of others when it cuts into profits? What? You mean we really have to put the food or drink we're selling into the food/drink we're selling? Do you know what that'd cost?Really, Harvey Wiley should be a lot more famous than he is. Raise a glass of (real) whiskey to him next time you sit down to a meal free of plaster, toxic dye and chalk--yes, we still have to worry about pure food and what's in it....but at least we have the right to make informed choices now and not just hope there's butter in the butter!

Like "The Poisoner's Handbook," Deborah Blum's previous poison-themed story about the birth of forensic science, "The Poison Squad" is an incredible piece of research. I can't imagine how many letters, newspaper and magazine articles, and documents Blum must have sifted through, because it seems like every paragraph in the book has at least one quote from a contemporary source. This not only gives the work in the book weight, but it also suggests the personalities of the various characters, particularly Harvey Wiley, and shines a light on all the political intrigue happened at the Bureau of Chemistry. All that research can, however, at times slow down the momentum of the book. It's so much information, that during certain passages you have to be invested in the book and the story of the Wiley's crusade against adulterating additions to food to keep reading.

Well-written, but not fully what I expected. Based on the title, I thought there would be more focus on the actual Poison Squad. If I had paid better attention to the subtitle, I might have realized that Dr. Harvey Wiley himself is the central subject of the book. And thank the stars for him and his crusading. He dedicated his career to protecting consumers from food and beverage manufacturers who sought to keep secret the fact that they were using unhygienic practices and dangerous chemicals in their products.But the book still wasn't quite what I expected and I can't see myself recommending it in general -- it will likely only appeal to American history/government/public health nerds. But hey, if you fall into that niche with me, then you'll at least appreciate Blum's work in documenting Wiley's career.

This is a fantastic and engaging book even for its grotesque description of adulterated and poisoned food in late 19th and early 20th century. I love all of this because it’s chemistry, and the main character food chemist Harvey Wiley is fascinating and a crusader for pure food. It’s scary to think there were no labels on food or ingredients listed. All that we take for granted. Until the first pure food and drug law in 1906, lots of food was not what you think it was. This is an important book to read during these times where the science is not in question about safety (not just food and drugs, but waste, climate change) but this administration seems to think so. Just like the Poisoners Handbook, Great book!

4.5*. Easy to read, lively, informative: all the things I want from casual history books. Despite the title, little page time is spent on the actual "Poison Squad" trials, alas, but there are enough gross details about the state of the food industry to feed my morbid curiosity. The creation of the FDA was a long and torturous road of failed legislation—Wiley didn't live to see the creation of the agency in its present form—and Blum meticulously lays it all out to get to an underlying point, which seems to be that government representatives have always been in bed with corporate interests. And so the history here remains as relevant as ever today, which is hammered home in the final pages with some equally queasy passages of recent regulatory rollbacks...

Just finished The Poison Squad: One Chemists’s Single Minded Crusade at the Turn of the Twentieth Century by Deborah Blum a scary book that recounts the sad state of US food safety in the early twentieth century: formaldehyde to extend shelf life in milk, chemical agents to bleach flour, spoiled meat packed in cans, food dyes made from harsh chemicals and the list goes on and on. The focus in the book is on Harvey Washington Wiley, a noted American chemist best known for his leadership in the passage of the landmark Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, but it also chronicles other “good guys” and bad guys. The trade off then as now is the profit margin of business versus consumer safety. Very interesting book!

I love well-written, engaging non-fiction, and Blum is 2 for 2 (The Poisoner’s Handbook) for me so far. This one has more of a cautionary message than the previous, illustrating that government protection of business over its citizens is nothing new, and that we’ve been fighting the same battle to value lives over dollars for generations. The subject of the book, Harvey Wiley, was totally unknown to me before reading, and Blum did a fantastic job of illustrating both the person and his outsized impact on our society. I found myself exasperated, angry, defiant, etc. right alongside him as he battled for food safety, and to me that’s the real trick of a book like this. A thoroughly entertaining (and infuriating read).

This was a fascinating and in depth look at the struggles of a dedicated man and his colleagues and associates to pioneer educated, informed change regarding food safety and regulation against the government agencies and food and agriculture industries that sought to stymie his efforts at every turn. Well researched and a good in depth read for anyone who might want to know just how horrific the conditions of our food and drink used to be at the turn of the 20th century and just how blithely indifferent big businesses were to the adverse affects on their consumers as long as they could make a profit. It's something we take for granted today, and this book makes me even more grateful for the hard work Dr. Wiley put into making sure our food and drink were safe for us to consume.

This book was fascinatingly disgusting. It really got me thinking about the changes in American’s diets after the depression, world war 1, and how that generation’s lives were really extended (into their late 70s and 80s), yet they had tons of health problems with the advent of canned foods, more shelf stable foods, chemicals in foods, etc. If you’re interested in food science, this is a good peek I to how far we’ve come and how far we have yet to go. If you’re one of those people who believe that the government needs to be smaller and the USDA and/or the FDA needs to be abolished, this should be required reading. Science is real and I’d rather have a poison squad looking out for my best interests.

Just an outstanding account of the efforts of Dr. Harvey Wiley, an early and passionate advocate for food/drug safety and purity. It's because of him that the 1906 Pure Food and Drug Act was passed, in addition to the 1938 Pure Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, which gave the new-ish FDA some teeth. He'a also the reason we have ingredient labels on food, and why when you buy whiskey, you get whiskey.And although food and drug manufacturers continue to use us as guinea pigs and to see what they can get away with (anybody remember the peanut butter-salmonella fiasco in 2008, or the Great Kale Crisis of the past few years?), it's because of Dr. Wiley that they can be held to account. He was a true *public* servant, and this is a story damned well told. Brava.

The Poison Squad by Deborah Blum, is a look into the way food was served up to Americans in the late 1800s and early 1900s. This true story of how food was made safe and the men and women who made it possible.The horrible way companies and manufacturers tried to make money off the lives of people is untenable. They used formaldehyde in milk killing thousands of children, decaying meat was preserved with both salicylic acid and borax.Unchecked and having no government regulation for basic safety or labeling they put profit before the health of their customers.Spookily, it sounds like some of the things that are happening in current times. Listeria, antibiotics, steroids fill our food supply and harm people every day. This was a surprisingly good read.

This was a disturbing and impressive read. Harvey Wiley was awesome. If you're at all interested in food science, the history of regulations related to global food systems particularly in the United States, then this story of the Father of the Pure Food Law of 1906 is a must-read. It's interesting to see what influence he garnered at the national level. He backed strong legislation to protect food systems. I wonder what a more grass roots effort would do to change food systems such as widespread disinterest in food additives or preservatives that have unscrupulous pasts. As a scientist, I'd like to better understand why substances are toxic and at what levels, but that's a formidable standard for regulatory efforts. Do we need a modern Poison Squad? Is this just Phase One Clinical Trials?

The Poison Squad was chosen as Madison, Wisconsin's Go Big Read book this year, and I can see why - there is so much to discuss about our progress in making our food (and drug) supply safe. Deborah Blum does a skilled job at dramatically presenting the appalling state of dishonesty that characterized some of the foods available to the poor at the turn of the 20th century. I found that part of the book particularly compelling - the story of the founding of the consumer protection agency not quite as much so. But I'm grateful to the individuals she profiles who dedicated their lives to the quest for life-saving inspections and labeling regulations.Please note that I don't use the star rating system, so this review should not be viewed as a zero.

An interesting tale of a government employee fighting against fake food at the beginning of last century. It shows both the progress we've made to root out really gross chemicals that used to be used and clearer rules about food safety. But also how the lobbying is so stacked against change. Interestingly it talks about how the move to purer food led to the Heinz ketchup we know today. People used to be wary of tomatoes because acidic juices would leach led from pewter plates and kill rich people. And it used to be watery and with recommendations for using homemade ketchup. Heinz started using more and real tomatoes to make the sauce thicker and advertising for it changed tastes and expectations.

This book is disgusting. I am not referring to the spoiled milk and decaying meat “refreshed” by formaldehyde, or the candy dyed with lead and copper, or ... (don’t want to give away too much.) It’s disgusting how so many people and so many organizations were able to successfully push back and fight regulations intended to make food safe. For decades. Wow. I see many parallels with today’s fight against Covid-19, and as the author noted, the fight for environmental regulation. It just breaks my heart. I gave the book 4 (not 5) stars because I was hoping for more of a science and gross-factor type read. I should have known this was a political read. I learned a lot and am grateful for the knowledge. I wish the whole country (planet?) would read this story on the fight for/against human health.

Wow! My family worried about me reading this book because I might decide that I won't eat anything. I had to remind them that I was reading about events from 100 years ago. The fight for pure food and medicine is a more drawn out fight than I learned in high school. I learned that after publication of The Jungle that the FDA was created. New, weak laws were enacted, but it took years of fighting to get our food, drink and medicine pure, read safe. I recommend this book strongly. We all need to know about Harvey Washington Wiley and the young civil servants who volunteered for the poison squads.I won a copy of this book through Goodreads.

This is a book about the history of food safety in US. It is not just story of food safety, it is a story of a movement to have safe food. It involve people in the government, among activist and corporations. The battle for food safety is a long one, corporations fight against it. But the people wants it, government in the middle. Occasionally on the side of corporation, but with some inside for the people. There is a hero in the story. In a way, it is not too different from struggle to a cause now. This book is a good reminder that many causes take a long time to do, and need to involve many people. Not just corporations, not just government, also the people. Highly recommended

The Poison Squad excellent look at the life and work of Harvey Washington Wiley, a crusader for pure food and drug and consumer safety. This book is rich with details that will keep readers engaged in the story. Wiley was a character, and his big personality and tireless efforts to protect the American public from harmful food and drink practices is one of the many strengths of this book. Deborah Blum is clearly an excellent researcher, and this book was so fascinating. It is amazing how political scandals over 100 years ago mirror current scandals we have today. Highly recommended to fans of history, chemistry, or politics.

The well-told story of Harvey Washington Wiley and his crusade for pure food and oversight of the food manufacturing companies and hence the health of America is chilling in its relevance based on current events. While at times a catalog of details, this book is a page-turner. While a serious academic historical account, it is laced with the personal side, subtle humor, and critically related threads (such as the women's suffrage movement). It remains remarkably nonjudgmental or partisan. I learned a great deal and reflect on my past lack of knowledge in this area despite being a physician who works to improve community health on a scale larger than with individual patients.

During the late 19th and early 20th century, Chief Chemist of the Dept. of Agriculture Harvey Wiley began his crusade against the purveyors of tainted foodstuffs in the US. The beginnings of his campaign coincided with Sinclair Lewis's scathing depiction of the Chicago meat packing industry. Deborah Blum compellingly tells the story of Wiley's lifetime long crusade to improve the quality of American food, drink, and drugs and to rein in corporate America's never ending attempts to add unhealthy ingredients. She traces the history of the 1906 Safe Food Act and the interesting cast of characters on either side of the battle.

If you, like me, are listening to the audiobook, skip the first chapter. The book begins with a list of people mentioned in the book and for some reason, the audiobook did the same thing. (I would have recommended ending with that or skipping it, it's impossible to follow aurally.) The book starts after the list.I was never so appreciative of labels and the Food and Drug Administration than after reading this. Wow. For all the weird stuff that gets in our food now, it's nothing compared to the turn of the 20th century and what went on then. It was interesting to see the Pure Food group and how it echos the Organics and local foods movement today.

Deborah Blum has such a gift for taking complex, potentially dry and boring subjects and turning them into clearly told drama. Normally science talk puts me to sleep, but she does a fantastic job of breaking it down into easy-to-understand language and helping the reader see what's at stake. I thoroughly enjoyed this book, and it made me grateful anew for all the food safety laws and regulations. The epilogue was a sobering reminder that we can't sit on our laurels and complacently assume these problems are now behind us, but that food safety remains an urgent concern, and that the Trump administration is even now working to weaken regulation.

I loved the book. Some parts were a tiny bit confusing, particularly the character intro in the front, I wish it had been in the back because it felt like I was bombarded with names that meant nothing to me yet. Also, numbering the character bios and super-scripting which name goes with which bio would have been very helpful for the first few chapters. Overall, once I got past that and had the cast of players set in my mind it was a very good read. Incredibly informative, I'm going to give it to my very conservative father for his birthday to see if having Republicans as the heroes of the story will get him on board with the idea of government regulation for the good of the citizenry.

The first part of the book is so powerful, the second half made me loathe that US food and FDA policy is made my Congress and at the whim of political gain. This book should have sections that are required reading for food/agricultural policy students. Absolutely essential reading if you want to understand why people are addicted to conspiracy theories about food and pharmacological practices in the USA. Folks, science literacy matters, but so does our ability to move science policy forward—this book does a great job showing us just how bad we are at both. It’s a miracle we’ve survived as a species.

Equal parts appalling and fascinating, Blum takes a deep dive into the crusade of Harvey Washington Wiley to save the American public from questionable, false and downright dangerous foodstuffs. Focusing on the USDA's regulation of food and drugs from the late 19th to early 20th century, the story has eerie similarity to much of today's political climate as industry backed legislators battle (often winning) against those who put the consumer and American people first. Any dry overly political portions of the book are balanced by hair raising descriptions of ingredients and manufacturing conditions that would be beyond unthinkable today

For those who went to sleep thinking that our food safety is a given, it's not. Never has been. There are forces at work now doing their damnedest to undermine food safety on multiple fronts. Our FDA and USDA have been taken over by corporate forces that are bent on complete deregulation. Even now, USDA inspectors are being fired and the meat industry, slaughter houses included, are being allowed to "inspect themselves". Poisons are being sprayed on monocrops and vegetation near water sources in insanely unsafe amounts.This is a history of those who actually fought, and won, for safe food, beverages, drugs and practices that promote the General Welfare. The struggle continues . . .

HON’s version of the facts ties with the New York Times database of past articles, while PSVF’s does not, see below)At the beginning of PS Chapter 14 entitled ’The Adulteration Snake (1911-1912)', PSVF claims that:2- Wilson asked McCabe to deliver the news to Wiley et al. - (Nothing of the sort in HON)3- Wilson asked McCabe because he did not want to deal with the problem himself - (Nothing of the sort in HON, obviously since point 2 is not even mentioned)4- McCabe waits until Friday July 15th, 1911 to deliver the message to Wiley et al. - (Nothing of the sort in HON, based on the very tight timeline between President Taft’s decision - July 7th, 1911 according to HON - and the leak in the New York Times later on - July 12th, 1911 - it seems unlikely that there was much delay in the charges being presented to Wiley et al. especially when one considers that this sequence of events occurred with the technological resources of 1911)5- McCabe waits until this date because he knew that Wiley was not present and that he therefore would not need to personally confront Wiley on that day - (Nothing of the sort in HON, obviously since point 2 is not even mentioned)6- McCabe asked Bigelow or Kebler to deliver the news to Wiley - (Nothing of the sort in HON, obviously since point 2 is not even mentioned)7- McCabe asked Bigelow or Kebler to do so because he didn’t want to do it himself - (Nothing of the sort in HON, obviously since point 2 is not even mentioned)8- Wiley was not at his office on the Friday, when McCabe informed the others of the charges - (HON describes that Wiley et al. are all informed of the charges on the same day, Saturday)9- Kebler found out about the charges prior to Wiley - (Nothing of the sort in HON, Kebler is not even mentioned in HON’s account)10- Bigelow felt a certain way prior to and after conveying the news to Wiley - (Nothing of the sort in HON)11- Wiley and Bigelow had a walk on or around the former’s farm, where Wiley would have explained why the news Bigelow brought made him happy - (Nothing of the sort in HON)12- The New York Times article that initially broke the story of the charges against Wiley et al. was published on July 20th, 1911 - (HON does not provide a specific date in the text, but in the notes, only the July 13th and July 17th, 1911 New York Time editions are referenced - I have independently found The New York Times article in question, but it is dated July 12th, 1911 - conceivably printed in the July 13th, 1911 edition - in any event at least a full week earlier than the PSVF)--- Update Feb/24/2020 (1 star... more like zero star)I reached out to Penguin, the book's publisher, this morning requesting clarification, since the author cannot or will not provide an answer.
