Which version actually happened? --- Update Feb/17/2020 (1 star)Still no news from the author, I think at this point the implications are pretty clear. At least one key passage is uber-dubious to me.--- Update Feb/12/2020 (2 stars)While it was an entertaining read, I have strong suspicions that - at least some of the - data presented is of dubious quality. I am in touch with the author, but so far I have not been able to get satisfactory answers to my basic questions... I would be highly careful in using/quoting anything from this book.--- Original Review (3 stars)Entertaining and Instructive...What I disliked:- In the edition I read, there were some issues with the dates listed, the few that I did check with the New York Times database don't match sometimes by just a day or two, but sometimes by a pretty significant amount. It is surely innocent, however it raises concerns as to the reliability of the historical facts presented, and I would encourage anyone needing to use this material as source for further study to verify the underlying events' dates.- It's rather subjective, but I personally felt that the love shown towards Heinz and its laudable commitment to quality, is a bit overdone and I would not be surprised if some readers feel that there's a bit of 'product placement / infomercial' advertising happening here (though Kraft-Heinz surely needs all the help it can get these days, sadly).

A story about the fight to put some standards in place regulating food and labeling, basically balancing public health needs and commercial interests. Seems like the story followed the career of one chemist at the USDA in the early 20th century and then mostly stopped after he retired. I guess the moral here is that when given the opportunity, businesses will always choose to protect their economic interests over nutrition and food safety for consumers. Seems that nothing has changed there. (I learned that Monsanto has always been an evil company.)Great narrator; she also did White Trash by Nancy Isenberg, Brooklyn by Colm Toibin, and Dark Money by Jane Mayer.

Blum did a great job of describing the challenges that Harvey Wiley faced as head of the Chemistry Division of the USDA from the late 1800s to the early 1900s. What I found most interesting was that there was so much public support for Wiley's crusade against toxic additives in food, while it was largely corporations (including an early incarnation of Monsanto) that were aligned against him and other food purity activists. And, of course, corporations often had allies in Congress and other governmental agencies, including the USDA. It's a timely and optimism-inducing read since we're once again facing determined corporate efforts to remove regulations intended to protect consumers.

This is an interesting book. It reinforces how hard it can be to get government to not be captured by industry, and makes me appreciate regulations that I've taken for granted, such as accurately labeled food and drink, food that doesn't kill me, etc. And the same fights we've had in government today were happening then, in exactly the same way: government agencies whose roles are intended to protect consumers are thwarted to actually menace consumers and protect industry. People like Wiley are so precious, and are so uncommon! Blum does a good job presenting the character of the times, she tells an engrossing story. I definitely would read other books she has written.

This book serves a couple of uses. First, it's an effective diet book. You'll be looking at all your food suspiciously. And it's also a damning indictment of removing federal regulations. I was a little disappointed that the science was less featured than it was in The Poisoner's Handbook: Murder and the Birth of Forensic Medicine in Jazz Age New York but the history lesson is timely and relevant.

It very interesting. It's hard to believe what was passed off to consumers as food in the late 1800 and 1900. The labeling of food we are accustomed to now was a hard fight. Food manufactures fought labeling and adulterations of food and drugs again and again. Sometimes people died from additives. The manufactures did not care. Now we can feel fairly safe that sugar actuarily is sugar when listed on a food label. Same for many other products. One dear to my heart is maple syrup. Now you can read a product label and know you are getting corn syrup disguised as male syrup.

This is a good lesson on politics that is germane even today. Here is the birth of the FDA. Without two things, it wouldn't have happened. The chief chemist (Dr Wiley) was the great advocate supported by a vast majority of consumers - who were vocal. The villains were big food business in cahoots with the lawmakers and the bureaucracy. You can be glad today that you don't have formaldehyde in your milk and many other things. Lessons here need to be applied to the gun laws and environmental protection. Read and learn.

So here's the thing: I read The Poisoner's Handbook, which she wrote a few years ago. I thought it was extremely well written, informative, engaging, etc. This book?I was confused....there was a lot said on Wiley's stand against sodium benzoate but not so much on how it turned out. It's still in our drinks today, so I'm assuming that means it's safe? Was Wiley indeed a single-minded crusader? This wasn't the only loose thread. It was very interesting but not nearly as good as it could have been.

The March selection for me from Just the Right Book is literally just the right book for me. A mix of science, history, and crusader changing the world for the noble cause of improving the quality of life. Staggering knowledge of what business was doing to consumers, what politicians were doing to protect business, and how much continues to my lifetime. In spite of so much change, so much technology, little has changed. The only lesson we learn from history? Well, you know the answer. Those wanting to return to the nostalgia, romanticize past certainly need to think again on that desire.

Great science writing about unsung heroes of food safetyI loved this book. It has everything I expect in good science writing: science that is clear and well-explained, historical background, politics, and biographical information about the protagonists. Indeed this book is mostly about politics and the steps taken to help improve food safety in the US. The main protagonist, Harvey Wiley, is an unsung hero, but hopefully Deborah Blum’s book will make people more aware of him. I strongly recommend this book for anyone interested in science.

Poison Squad is a biography of Dr. Wiley's life with a focus on his (and contemporary) food safety efforts. It is an interesting book with a well researched narrative that should remind us how bad things can get without regulations. However, I wish it had a little more philosophical discussion on what are good ways to regulate, and what can go wrong with regulation, rather than being a pure "this is what happened" narrative - I would have appreciated a little more critical analysis of the history rather than just statement of facts.

Interesting biography of Wiley, with great detail regarding the food safety issues of the time. (Often thought she might be writing about TODAY, rather than the 1800-1900s.) Was impressed with how Blum took the reader through the food industry, government, media, and consumer perspectives. Wiley turns them all on their ears and shook America into government and industry FOR the people rather than for their own interests. Interesting read, often redundant, but certainly informative and fascinating. Good read!

The high level of food safety we have today hasn't always been the case. This book traces the origin of the pure food movement and the role Dr. Harvey Wiley played in helping get such legislation enacted. The resistance by so many groups is staggering given the negative consequences of ingesting tainted food. More importantly the sacrifice that so many young men went through to verify the toxicity of additives is astounding. Seeing the struggle between public interest and business hasn't changed much in the last century is the hardest thing to stomach.

The book is very interesting and fascinating and without knowning anything about the start of FDA this gives a very good description of the issues the american food industry battled back then. Wiley is clearly an interesting character and very idealistic - impressive that he doesn't just quit but keeps fighting for what he believes. The historical facts are well founded and how it draws up parallels to today is very interesting indeed. It probably deserves 3.5 from me - it is not my main interesting but it did keep me fascinating from start to end. Worth a read.

This is probably a little dry if you’re not excited about the subject matter, as there are a lot of names and dates and details. There’s no challenging science. The story of Dr. Harvey Wiley as a public servant crusader for a safer food system was fantastic. You get a sense of him from details shared and it helps bring the subject to life. The Poison Squad itself is only a portion of the book, it is really the story of Dr Wiley’s career. I would appreciate a ‘sequel’ that talks about the current state of food regulations and ingredients and manufacturing.

Blum is not my favorite author - she tells a story in a straight-forward manner with few of the literary flourishes I tend to enjoy, even in non-fiction works. That said, the topic of this book was quite interesting (and horrifying), and was a quick read once you got through Wiley's early life and into the Poison Squad years. It's truly a stomach-churning work, however, and also depressing as you realize that we are just repeating history in many ways, and how evil corporate profiteers and the legislators who support them are exactly the same 100 years later.

If you eat or are interested in good food in the least, don't read this book. Seriously, another book that made me sick to my stomach. It is amazing that only through the hard work and seriously strong will and perseverance of a few people that we now have "safer" food on the shelves. I say "safer" because not not sure that flaming hot Cheetos could even qualify as food, no less safe. A classic example of what happens when big business/profits and the government/lobbyist's are in bed together. Yikes!!!

While there are certainly sections of this book that are rather dry, this is an important reminder of how hard we had to fight to get basic safety standards enacted for the general welfare. And the reader feels pretty good about that progress. Right up to the epilogue, where Blum reminds us that in 3 short years Trump and his cohorts are plunging us back to a time where government legislation served the interests of businesses that can afford to buy off the legislators, rather than the American people.

I would consider this more of a biography than a history or a presentation of "social problems," which is how our library catalogs it. The book itself was a compelling read and a quick read for nonfiction. I agree with the other reviewers who wanted more information about the men in the Poison Squad, the effect of additives on their bodies, their recovery, and whether or not those additives are still in use today.I would have given this 3 stars except the plethora of reviews questioning the veracity and authenticity of the author's sources has given me pause.

Never Trust Any GovernmentGreat read about a cadre of individuals in the early days of the 20th Century who fought for food purity and regulations and laws to insure this would happen. Led by Harvey Wiley, inroads were made to protect consumers, in spite of opposition by businesses who put profits before individual and collective well being and government officials who were influenced by those businesses as well as hedged on language that would make enforcement of laws governing food purity difficult.

This is fascinating account of the manufactured food industry in late 18th and early 19th centuries and how U.S. govt chemist, Dr. Harvey Wiley (truly a hero) fought to educate the public and impose regulations to clean it up. The descriptions of the preservative and adulteration practices of the time will horrify and disgust you. Admittedly the last half of this dragged a bit for me, with a lot of science and details about the politics of enacting "pure food" legislation.

Extremely eye-opening account of the beginning of food and drug regulation in the US,and necessary reading for anyone under the illusion that food in the past was always pure and unprocessed,or that corporate interests pushing against regulation is a modern phenomenon.Not recommended for reading while eating, as the food additives used and horrific preparation conditions described are quite stonmach-turning

It seems hard to believe, but at one point, a number of American food manufacturers added Formaldehyde to their products, like canned meat and milk. They added so much, they became known as "embalmed meat" and, worse,"embalmed milk". There are plenty of disgusting nuggets of information in this story of one man's crusade to clean up American food production. Unfortunately it's rather dull reading, a bit of a slog. Too much old school American politics for my taste.

A fascinating read about the pursuit of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 and the problems enforcing it. In a talk to chemists visiting from Europe, he [Harvey Wiley] said, “Man’s highest ambition in this country is to strive to be the equal of woman.”-Deborah Blum (The Poison Squad: One Chemist Single-Minded Crusade for Food Safety at the Turn of the Twentieth Century p 108)https://nicolewbrown.blogspot.com/201...

I loved The Poisoner's Handbook, so I was really excited to read this. Unfortunately, the title is somewhat misleading as very little of the book is about the Poison Squad itself. It is almost completely devoted to Dr. Wiley's altercations with hostile politicians and industry leaders. While this is no doubt historically accurate and an important part of the story, it did not make for gripping reading and left me still wanting to know more about the heroic group for which the book is named.

WOW! This book was great. I read it over spring break in 4 days. Mrs. Blum educates, scares you, and draws you in. It is a story of perseverance, science, and how some people in government only try to serve their own best interest. So grateful for all the hard work that has helped to keep my family and I safe and healthy. I feel bad for all the unfortunate people in the late 1800s who had no knowledge of what they were eating from day to day.

interesting book about the the food industry as it was trying to walk the line between safety and profit. one chemist went on a mission to protect the integrity of foods, he had both friends and enemies in high places. then it led to the FDA and the war ended with public awareness of the situation and the lack of regulation. this situation is still in the petroleum industry. its interesting to know that situation in the US in terms of food safety was just just China's right now.

Confession: I did not finish this book! I learned a lot in the first half but then just simply found it so repetitive that I couldn't stick with it. I had no idea that our food was so disgustingly tainted (at a time when the rest of the world had figured out safe practices) or that things like milk and meat were once so rancid and doctored that many children died. We are better today but not 100%.

The Poison Squad is a well researched book detailing the fight throughout U.S. history for food safety. I have a very strong stomach, and this book made me nauseated at times describing things that have been added to foods throughout the years. Ultimately, this is also a description of greed as well, as companies were willing to have children die or people become ill to achieve higher profits.

Once again, Deborah Blum has written a wonderful, readable, fascinating book. This book details the history of food protection in the U.S.A. I was fascinated to learn how food protection came about and more than a little disturbed by various events that took place to lead to it. This book also details politics and consumers versus industry that can be filed under "the more things change, the more things stay the same."

This was just a solid micro-history. The epilogue commenting on the Trump administration's assault on these hard-won consumer protections was a bit out of place, with a clearly different tone, but very relevant.Just throw this book at every libertarian you know who squawks about the glory of the free market and how government regulation does nothing but impede business. Wiley is rolling in his grave right now with our constant attempts to roll back a century of progress.

Borrowed this book months ago and begun reading it, the amount of times I've gasped, widened my eyes and cussed at what companies placed in their products. I've just started a subject called 'Healthy Public Policy' my appreciation and admiration for figures in history such as Wiley himself have only grown since. One thing for sure, never take the food and health safety regulations for granted. Amazing read, definitely recommend.

Reading this really makes you appreciate the FDA. Back before the 30's, there were essentially no rules concerning food production. If the milk was a little old, just put in some formaldehyde.Want greener peas, copper sulfate is the answer. And why not put lead based dyes in candy.When politicians talk about removing regulations to encourage innovations, this is the world they want to go back to.Harvey Wiley is a true hero.

This was a dense book - good, interesting and engaging - but dense. We read it as part of a workplace book club and I enjoyed it, but had a hard time finishing due to the amount of brainpower I needed to read. Definitely worth picking up and reading if you're interested in where your food comes from, how we label and talk about food and what "good" food is, but give yourself a few hours at a time to really get into it.

Gripping.How a story about a chemist that spans the years between 1880 and 1930 can be described as gripping, I don't know, but there it is. Blum flawlessly brings together science, history, and politics to tell the story of how this country struggled for decades to regulate its own food supply, and the story of the flawed man who never stopped crusading for "pure food". The book is particularly timely as we enter a new era of mania for industry deregulation. A must-read!

The history of food safety in the U.S. is shocking! The author tells the story of Harvey Wiley and his efforts to protect the consumer. He went to battle with many lawmakers and the industry leaders that were pressuring them. Unfortunately it always took poisonings and deaths to finally get the attention of Congress. The book is very thorough in recounting history and therefore is heavy with the names of all involved.

Non fiction book. Very interesting. Especially when you hear people say they wish we could go back to the old days before our food was processed. The main focus of this book is without some oversight all of these food/beverage companies only cared about the bottom line. The food was laced with so many bad things. The ones that suffered the most were the young, poor and old. Oversight of our food is crucial. And labels need to be read.

Engrossing read, definitely inspired me to get more involved in advocacy. And so prescient for today’s time! Highly highly recommend! The only reason I docked a star was for the lack of reminders of who the characters are (so many new people are introduced, it was sometimes hard to remember who was who. Blum referred to characters by the their last name after only mentioning first names just once— it would’ve been super helpful to include first names again appropriately in subsequent mentions).

Enjoyed the book and the story of Harvey Wiley's life and determination to make food food safe. Interesting that we now have a clean label emphasis today. I haven't read anything else about about the and struggles to enact laws to regulate food and additives. Written with the viewpoint of Wiley struggles.Was disappointed that Deborah Blum decided to show a political bias with her epilogue. Recommend it.

I found this a fascinating book on not just the history of the FDA, but of US history as a whole. I'm not normally a big one for modern history but this was well written and informative. I think it's well worth reading because, as the author points out near the end, the current administration is doing everything it can to undo all the good that was started by Harvey Washington Wiley to protect the citizens of the US from harmful chemicals and additives.

Interesting history of Dr. Wiley, head chemist for the Department of Agriculture and his crusade to get a Pure Food and Drug Act passed in the early 1900's. The legislation was eventually passed in 1906, but because of government interference and backing of corporations, never lived up to Dr. Wiley's ideals. Nonetheless, he was successful in getting formaldehyde out of our food supply. Also interesting that Dr. Wiley fought to get saccharine banned but wasn't successful.

This was a hard read for me as the political environment was not much different then today. Dr. Wiley was a dedicated Scientist in bringing about food safety in America. My stomach could not take reading this book all the way through with out taking a break occasionally. I finally got through because I want to give it to my oldest grandson for his birthday. It is an important book. I do wonder what Dr. Wiley would think of our diet in America today.

I'm giving it a 4 because of what I learned from it. But it wasn't an easy read due to the topic matter of how dangerous - even lethal, the food was during the late 1880's and the early 1900's. No "watch dogs" - no regulations. This was especially true for the lower economic levels. It covers the whole meat packing scandal written about by Upton Sinclair. This could have benefited from tighter editing.

Great book on why government regulation rulesGreat story about hard-fought protections introduced through decades of passionate advocacy and tenacity. In some ways inspiring, and in some ways, the more things change the more they stay the same. I wish they had done more of a "murderers row" of the chemicals they talked about instead of just the individuals involved.

A well-told story of that unsexy topic, reform, and how hard and persistently Dr. Wiley had to fight for it. Lots of gross stuff to keep me reading through the long bureaucratic infighting. And even before the epilogue drew the connection directly, a clear connection to the pro-business, pro-capital regulatory climate of today.

I thought I’d read this book non stop and not be able to put it down. It was well researched, well written and interesting but man was it tedious and long. I had weeks where I didn’t pick it up. However, this is an interesting look into our food history and the Wiley’s fight for regulations and protection of all Americans.

This was a fascinating look at how a scientist, Harvey Washington Wiley, fought food manufacturers to insure safe and properly labeled foods. He ran experiments to prove that certain food additives were dangerous. It's hard to believe the disgusting things that were hidden in food. It makes me grateful for food regulations and ingredients listed properly on labels.

A lengthy & involved read but well worth it. I’m constantly being reminded that ignorance is such bliss & this book is no exception. The similarities of 100 years ago to today are startling when it comes to food adulteration & the way lobbyists for big companies are still controlling the government

Things I didn't know before reading: formaldehyde used to be a preservative for milk, saccharine was Theodore Roosevelt's go to sweetener, and how rotten eggs were often used in baked cakes. I had already read Upton Sinclair's _the Jungle_ and knew the role it played, but this book added a different perspective on food safety and labeling. Interesting read.

Not as gripping a tale as I had hoped but I am still glad I read it. The first chapters about food contamination were pretty disgusting. It’s a wonder anyone survived! There was less about the actual Poison Squad than you would think from the book title, and more about the man who created it (Wiley). I am certainly more thankful now for his work than I had any idea I needed to be.

Maybe not the best book to read during my lunch hour, but still enlightening. Especially about why alcohol labeling laws differ from other food/drink/drug laws -- spoiler alert, it's just politics. I do wish the book had included a modern analysis of what each preservative actually does to the human body, rather then solely relying on the observations of the Poison Squad.

A solid and informative read. Passing and enforcing laws against the interests of capital has always been an uphill slog in America, as this book so clearly demonstrates, and the only path to success lies in not giving up. It took more than twenty (20!) years to pass legislation requiring U.S. food manufacturers to not put harmful or poisonous substances in food, and a further thirty (30!) years of fighting those same manufacturers about what qualifies as harmful and poisonous. In the meantime, documented hundreds (and surely many more) of American citizens were sickened and killed by various chemicals used by companies to make their food look more cheerful and appear fresher. This is the story of that struggle, using the career of one key chemist as the central story, and featuring many other activists, in careful and entertaining detail. Of course, in making these changes, the U.S. lagged behind Europe. La plus ca change! Or, as they say in the swamplands, MAGA!

We take for granted the labels on foods. Just imagine if producers were not required to put labels on food - well that's what is was like in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. If not for a handful of dedicated chemists and the strong will on one in particular, the interest of business certainly would have had an impact on the longevity of our lives.

This is a marvelously told story of the fight to protect against the adulteration of our food (and drugs). It's also a very insightful description of the ins, outs, ups and downs of policymaking in the US. Blum is among the very best science writers around. The book is especially timely given the Trump administration's attacks on many consumer protection regulations.

I've heard the urban legend of how, after reading Sinclair's "The Jungle" Teddy Roosevelt pushed for pure food legislation. "The Poison Squad" gives the true story and background -- TR not so much the hero -- to the push to clean up the food system in the U.S.We should still be pushing for pure food laws AND enforcement.

Audio Book - LOVED listening to Kirsten Potter narrate The Poison Squad. Great voice. The book itself? Definitely not as interesting as Deborah Blum's previous book, The Poisoner's Handbook. A little dry and bland. Not necessarily her writing though - hard to make the history of food safety in the US thrilling.

Blum's The Poisoner's handbook is one of the best books I've read so maybe this couldn't have been anything but a mild disappointment. It's in the same vein (there are threats to the population, so science dudes come up with a solution) but in the end, this really was about food safety and the FDA and you can only make it so sexy.

3.5. You'll never look at milk, bleached flour or ketchup the same way again. It's very important to realize food safety is an ongoing battle and we still need to fight and fight hard for the proper legislation. The book itself can get a little bogged down in places because the war never seems to end but that's sort of the point isn't it?

I finished it! Read this for a book club or I never would have made it through the endless ways of saying the same thing over and over. A careful edit would have made it into a pamphlet, I think.But, I learned several historical things, so I’m glad to be finished with it and to return to my beloved fiction!

Fascinating look at Harvey Washington Wiley and his fight for food safety and consumer protection around turn of twentieth century. Scary some of the additives and processes used by companies - and many still fighting against regulation today. Interesting that Heinz was one of the few to agree with Wiley and produce pure products! (Own)

This was, for me, an interesting look at how government and industry have seemingly always had ties, the strength of which have been tested by numerous political figures and causes throughout history. It also served as additional encouragement to be conscious of food and drug labels because sadly, things are not always what they seem.

An interesting book about how the Food and Drug Administration came to be and the rough road that was traveled. Harvey Wiley was a dedicated warrior in the fight to get Pure Drug and Food regulations through the government. He never faltered in his fight no matter how tough the opposition was. He championed the cause to anyone that would listen and hopefully gain support to aid his cause.

An interesting look into the horrifying history of food contamination in the US and how one heroic man strove to rid the food system of it. Most of the events take place around the same time as The Jungle by Upton Sinclair and detail the repulsive and poisonous practices common at the time across all types of foods. It's a pretty easy listen and not too repetitious.

This was a very interesting read and novel outlining the quest for food safety. I've since started looking much more closely at labels and researching saccharin and other food additives. I had no idea how the FDA and USDA initially started looking into food safety. To the poison squad volunteers, they were brave!

I know I wouldn't have read this book if it wasn't a selection from my book club. The overall topic wasn't too exciting to me but I have to give props to Blum for all the research necessary to write this. Recommended for people interested in government oversight that benefits people not companies, fans of Sinclair's The Jungle, and science nerds.

I couldnt stand this book. It took me six weeks to finish. Somewhere in the 291 pages is a story, among the mass amount of proper nouns (names of people that are never again, named of colleges, names of organizations, etc.) that ultimately have no impact on the point of the book. I couldnt keep my attention on the book when I had to filter out half of its contents.

Great book! Informative and very compelling narrative. This certainly reversed my overly romantic ideas about just how 'pure' food might have been in 'the old days'. Makes me grateful for our current regulatory framework, and makes me wonder what we don't yet know about the things that are in our food today that have been believed to be innocuous, but might not be. So glad I read this!

I tend to enjoy books like this more when the real people are bigger characters in the story. It was a very interesting read about people who did an amazing thing to better humanity, but I don't feel like I knew them outside of that context so it read a bit more like a history lesson. Not bad, but I wasn't engrossed either.

This is an excellent history of attempts by chemists and particularly one man, Dr. Wiley to enact safety precautions for food in America in late 1800's and early 1900's. He was fought by lobbyists who urged Congress to protect industry at the expense of Americans dying from adulterated food. An example was formaldehyde in milk and borax in butter resulting in numerous deaths.

After reading this book I’ve gained a few things:1. A reluctance to eat anything that I didn’t watch growing2. A better understand if this history of our legislative system3. A good reminder that nothing ever changes if people don’t have the courage to fight to the bitter endOff to harvest some spinach from the porch and throw out the contents of my freezer!

We listened to this over the course of a couple drives to my family's house and found it very interesting. We didn't have any trouble following along, the reader was great and the material was very interesting. Even my non-scientist husband followed along.

This book is well written, very interesting, and highly disturbing. I tried to read this for the science and history of the subject, but I'm pretty sure I will never fully enjoy milk or candy again, so I had to stop halfway through.

This is the story of the beginning of the FDA and the troubles and funds that got allocated. Also fights between the company's did not want any regulations I am grateful all this succeeded for us to get safe food good book

Our country is in need of more activists like Dr. Harvey Washington Wiley. Especially now when the current administration is rolling back consumer and environmental protections for the benefit of businesses and the wealthy. Consumer safety must always prevail over corporate interests.

An interesting if somewhat slow-moving and repetitive read. Details the historical progression toward food safety legislation. Considering the current attitude from the white house toward regulation, I think this stuff is important to know. Let's not go back to the bad old days of food safety!

Really interesting and important subject matter but the book could've used a little more organization. It was easy to get lost among the various names after a while. Also depressing to see just how far back corporate influence in politics goes.

The same thing is going on with our food today as it was 100 years ago. Mega corporations trying to make money with at any cost. Mind blowing what they used to put in food and beverage (and probably still do to some degree)

Narrow focus, but if the subject sounds interesting to you then this book does an excellent job. Good blend of the overall situation and concrete examples. Also one of the few cases of nonfiction where the biography doesn't feel extraneous.

Fast-forward the date from the late 19th century by a couple of centuries, and this could easily read like a news story. I was frequently reminded of the saying "those who never learn from history are bound to repeat its mistakes." A must read.

this book simultaneously contributed to my depression and buoyed me up because:a) people do and have always cared more about money than actual human lives; and,b) other people are and always have been carrying the fire and fighting the good fight.

3.5 stars. I listen to the audiobook which helped it move along, I think that if you were trying to read the book that it might get a little bit dry. Definitely interesting though, and a little bit disturbing.

Another UW Go Big Read selection that does not disappoint! The fight within our political system to protect consumers instead of manufacturers has been going on for a long time. Very interesting read!

Good book; pretty quick read. I found it interesting some of the politics from 100 years ago went clearly across party lines (both parties generally in the pocket of business; not at all fighting for the common good).

Fascinating. Non finisher, only because I had other books with deadlines to read. Chilling to think not much has changed in a century of food safety legislation and political infighting. Makes me want to read Sinclair Lewis’ book, ‘The Jungle’... almost.

Phenomenal book that every American must read. The struggle for pure food laws are epic in Barrie and I can see this being made into a movie starring Tom Hanks! Exceptionally well researched. Loved the portions about Suffrage too.

This book had so many horrifying anecdotes; I no longer take for granted the basic food labels and the food safety of today. However, it was a long book and heavy on detail. Interesting, yes, but too much.

A frightening account of how food was often altered with poisonous fillers, sweeteners and artificial coloring which often caused illness and death, and the hero's who fought for government food safety regulations in the early 1900's.

It was very informational and made me really love Wiley, his wife, and the work they did. I did find myself skimming quite a bit as some of the monotonous (and lengthy) descriptions of the history and laws began to feel extremely repetitive. Otherwise, a great, informational read.

Beautifully written. A gripping story about a fight against industry to make food safe. I will never cease to be amazed at how willing certain soulless people are to add poison to food and to use deception to increase profits.

I think I would have enjoyed learning more about the actual poison panel, but this was really good and informative regardless. Now I am constantly finding myself looking at labels giddy in my recognition of a specific rule or law mentioned in the book.

This book was quite eye-opening! I thought food 100 years ago would be wholesome, with less adulteration than our food currently. Not at all the case, as this author points out in her well-researched book.

Not as engaging as The Poisoner's Handbook. Still well researched and well told, but perhaps only interesting enough to those already interested in the topic?I did appreciate the background on The Jungle and it's role in the getting 1906 act through Congress.

3.5 rounded downVery interesting! The book was more of a biography than I expected. It felt repetitive at points, I would have preferred to see some more scientific background or read more about the average American’s response.

Extremely well-researched, detailed historical timeline of government and politics. I was looking for more details on the actual food ingredients (cause it wasn't healthy) and lost interested quickly. Just not my kind of book.

It's wild that a book about a government chemist who was appointed in the 1890s, and his crusade for accurate labelling and banning outright dangerous products, could be so captivating. Very well written and engaging.

Interesting topics, but not sure the book needed to be as long as it was. I listened as an audiobook and the beginning part where the author lists all the people involved was a bit long and I fast forwarded as it was unnecessary.

Very informative and surprisingly readable given the subject matter.It gets pretty boring starting in the second half. But the important thing to remember is: In an unregulated environment, corporations will kill people if it increases their profits.

The book itself was good, but it just wasn't my cup of tea. A more scientific mind would really enjoy the book. Sometimes you just don't 'click' with a book but it's not the author or the reader's fault. I would recommend this book if you are interested in the topic.

A fantastic book which tells how the food and drug laws were developed over years of struggle. We are so blessed to have them protecting us at this time....after years of battling to make laws that protect us.

This recounting of the food industry in the early 1900's and the fight for proper food laws is both riveting and disgusting. If you aren't already, it will make you completely rethink the food industry and where your food comes from.

A great account of a man that despite being knocked down at every corner kept to his undying truth and self worth by promoting un-preserves few, promoting his wife suffragette and ultimately laying the ground work for the FDA. Great read packed with lots of historical information.

This deep dive into a consequential epoch of food safety law in the United States is well-researched and well laid out. Though I at times wished it were a tad broader than the “one chemist’s crusade” that’s advertised on the tin, well, I can’t blame it on faulty labeling.

"I liked it," feels about right.The assertion that not allowing businesses to lie to the public about what their products contain as "anti-American" is so, so timely. It's almost comforting to know the United States has always been this way.

It was a slow start, but I started to get wrapped up in the details and intrigue of Harvey Wiley and his legions of concerned consumers fighting for honesty and transparency in food manufacturing and marketing.

This book documents the history of regulation of food labeling and safety. It was a difficult read...I hope I lost some weight! What was most discouraging is that it echoes the battle between business interests and consumer protection regulation that continues today.
Wow, what an interesting book.
A look at what food, drugs and drink had in them before the days of FDA regulations. I only wish there had been more personal examples of people being poisoned that had been described.
This was a great read about the early days of food regulation. Very readable and engaging. It is also just amazing to realize what was in food.
Excellent - the history of the fight to regulate food and drugs. A battle that is clearly still being waged.
Frighteningly fascinating.
From the moment I started reading, I couldn’t put down this book. For anyone that has an interest in food, chemistry, politics, history, or backstabbing corruption, this book is a must read for you.
Fascinating!
This book makes you think about manufacturers of food products adulterating their food, and it makes you appreciate the FDA. Mostly about the 1900's, the problems still exist though.
3.5 The first 1/2 was really interesting, but I wanted more context for what was going on at the time. Political scheming gets tedious.
Horrifying by nature but awesome writing and fascinating subject! I loved it.
How are any of us alive
Unfortunately relevant to today's world, will make you feel very sad about capitalism.
The first half of this book was engaging, but it fell off once the Pure Food Act was passed.
Fascinating, disgusting, eye-opening, but repetitive after a while.
Informative on an easily understood level. Quite the eye-opener and make sure you're not eating while reading
Complex history of the central figures around what became the US FDA. Important to note that there is a little significant history of self regulation failing.
One of my favorite all-time authors. Superbly written.
What surprised me most was that toxic additives and proper labeling were and issue back to the early 1800s.
What a great work of writing! A wonderful story about the life and work of someone who actually made a difference that we ca appreciate today. Thank you Stacy Horn for the recommendation.
Actually a litte bit modified biography of the staring Wiley. Quit annoying and not like other Blum's bookd.
